Mules, horse’s and zebras are from the same family.   “All you need to know is that animals like horses, donkeys and zebras have all evolved from the same family called equidae. The fact that in turn those offspring are sterile shows that within their own kind they have evolved away from fecundity.

Hi, I studied genetics university 20 years ago. There is one thing I've never been able to understand. In the evolutionary process, how do chromosome counts and other rearrangements happen? Horses and donkies have a common ancestor. At some point there was a mutation that changed the number of chromisones in one of the lineages. But wouldn't that individual no be able to breed with others in its population? Furthermore, individuals with  that mutation would have to replicate so successfully that they surplant to original form. Di we know how this process occurs?

Something I've been wondering about:
How did species evolve different number of chromosomes?
At some point, one member of the species would have gotten an extra chromosome. Hypothetically, a chromosome splits or maybe it is born with an extra copy due to meiosis misfires.
Wouldn't that member of the species have non-homologous chromosomes from every other member of their species? Isn't this what makes mules sterile?
Would two members need to have similar or analogous mutations to be able to breed a new species?

I have for a long time enjoyed the videos put out by SciShow. But I am starting to wonder if the talent on screen is merely reading scripts. For all these videos they seem to be completely devoid of any personality and all videos on this channel seem to have the same tone. One would expect that if the person on camera has any exciting or different facts to say, the video would have a slightly different tone or unique personality.

From what I've deduced , this channel consists of actors looking at a camera and imitating Steve Jobs by touching finger tips together, trying to appear sincere. They are presenting somewhat recent science related topics that is not that revolutionary from the science community in a consumerist friendly way, without actually explaining any detail.

I guess this is good since people get exposed to this information, but it is really uninspiring to anyone with a science based background.

I love that his channel is encouraging people to think about science, but the scripts they are clearing using makes me loose interest.

What is often left out of explaining that mules are sterile is that some species' hybrids are fertile. And that the definition of species as a group that can produce fertile offspring together falls apart when you look into the edge cases.

In our history we have interbred with different different species of humans and our genome now contains some of theirs.

The phenomenon of ring species shows it's hard to define the species boundaries. if A can breed with B, and B can breed with C, but A cannot breed with C, where do you draw the line?
The question is how horses and donkeys together can produce viable offspring in the first place.

There are definitely exceptions to this idea that difference in chromosome count leads to genetic incompatibility.  Human ancestors must have been such a case at one time, as humans have 23 pairs of chromosomes, one of which is the fusion of two chromosomes that non-human apes (with 24 pairs) have.  At some point there must have been a mixed population, even if only for a brief time, where chromosome counts were different across individuals within the population.

2:25 That was a weird jump. The odd chromosome was always going to be unmatched since there's no other chromosome. It has nothing to do with pairs being made up of similar or different chromosomes.

Horses and Donkeys are not "totally difference species". They are _very closely related species_. They are so closely related, they can mate and produce offspring. The reason they are considered cladistically distinct species is precisely because those offspring are sterile.

It is a very strange way to open your video saying they are "totally different spedies" when the whole video is based on the fact they can have hybrid matings that produce offspring, which contradicts the "totally different species" statement.
